title-group.article-title: From “Natural” to “Ecosocial Flourishing”: Evaluating Evaluative Frameworks

abstract.p: Evaluative terms are a crucial part of the environmental discourse. These terms, and the evaluative frameworks in which they are imbedded, serve as important guides to action. “Natural,” a term commonly used as a positive evaluation, is problematic because it can both justify unfair social relations and obscure the connections between humans and the rest of nature. “Sustainable,” another popular term, is extremely malleable, and is too often elaborated in frameworks that are neither socially nor ecologically responsible. The term “sustainable” is sometimes used in the framework of ecosystem health, but even this approach can fail to highlight the interconnectedness of social and ecological systems. The framework of ecosocial flourishing, introduced in this article, is better suited for highlighting the interconnected nature of the world and for drawing attention to questions of environmental justice. Evaluative terms (like “natural”) and frameworks (like “ecosocial flourishing”) are part of larger narratives that help people make sense of their interactions with, and emotional responses to, the non-human world.

ref.mixed-citation: Throughout this essay, I will use “social” to refer to human societies. While I recognize that other animals have complex societies, I wish to avoid the cumbersome locution “human social.”

While it is not the aim of the essay to defend a particular vision of environmental ethics, I will assume throughout that we should recognize the value and promote the flourishing of both human and non-human life, realizing that such flourishing entails conflicts and trade-offs. Arguably, a holistic ethics would be more attuned to human and non-human interconnectedness than an individualistic one. However, certain elaborations of deep ecology (a holistic philosophy) have been accused of ignoring the connection between social and ecological concerns. See, for instance, Bookchin (1987).

I realize that the termsphronesis(practical wisdom) has historically been tied to virtue ethics. This is not an implicit endorsement of virtue ethics on my part, but rather a recognition of how virtue ethics has reinvigorated the discussion of practical wisdom amongallethicists, including deontologists and consequentialists. Hursthouse (2008) states, “Even many deontologists now stress the point that their action-guiding rules cannot, reliably, be applied correctly without practical wisdom, because correct application requires situational appreciation” (under “Virtue, practical wisdom andeudaimonia”).

There is a tradition among humanists to use “natural” as a negative evaluative term. In the words of John Stuart Mill, “[a]ll praise of Civilization, or Art, or Contrivance, is so much dispraise of Nature; an admission of imperfection, which it is man's business, and merit, to be always endeavoring to correct or mitigate” (1969,381). However, the dominant current use of the term, especially in environmental discourse, is a positive one.

While it does notnecessarilylead to such obfuscation, often, in practice, if does. I support a human-inclusive definition of nature, but it is well beyond the scope of this paper to argue for such a contentious thesis. I would only note that a variety of influential thinkers, from Lynn White (1967) to Val Plumwood (2002) to Arne Naess (1989), have blamed the current ecological crisis in part on theories separating humans from nature.

As Deborah Blum notes, “We kill lots of animals—the ones we find annoying, destructive or unsafe. We regularly employ toxic substances against rats, insects, prairie dogs, coyotes and invasive fish, and yet we are shocked when those same lethal substances affect us” (2007, par.10).

Even places that seem lacking in non-human nature can be the source of rich relationships. When I interviewed Arne Naess (2006) in his nursing home, he marveled at the beauty of the plant on the coffee table between us, musing, “It looks so happy. It is opening up to us. It is a shame that we cannot stop and give it its due respect, staring at it in silence for an hour.”

For the rest of this essay, I will put “natural” in scare quotes, given my skepticism about its coherence and usefulness, expressed above. Note that the entire weak vs. strong sustainability debate, by relying on the term “natural,” reinforces the perceived divide between humans and the rest of nature. Nonetheless, as Rolston (2000) recognizes, his definition of ecosystem health relies on a mistaken notion of ecosystem stability.

For examples of such societies, see Anderson (2005), Kimmerer (2000), and Apffel-Marglin and Parajuli (2000). The first two discuss Native American societies, while the third discusses a specific community in India. While there is currently a vigorous debate over the ecological sensitivity of “traditional” societies, whether they are indigenous or simply outside the purview of industrial development, the above authors provide compelling arguments that at leastsometraditional societies show significant ecological foresight. As Kent Redford (1990) makes clear, it is reductive to portray all indigenous people as “ecologically noble savages,” but it is equally reductive to portray them all as ecologically destructive.

Given my above rejection of Aristoteliantelos, I am not advocating an Aristotelian definition of flourishing. Rather, I choose the term because it promotes positive, constructive thinking about the best life for humans and non-humans alike.

The literature on this subject is incredibly complicated and its results are inconclusive. At first, diversity and stability were taken to be mutually reinforcing (a view still held unquestioningly by many ecophilosophers). A landmark study by Robert May suggested just the opposite, and subsequent research has yielded a bewildering variety of results. As a survey of this issue points out, much of the confusion is due to the proliferation of definitions of stability ( Ives and Carpenter
2007).

Paul Shepard (qtd. in Devall and Sessions1985,172–74), for instance, sees agriculture as the beginning of humans separation from nature and calls for an end to all domestication of both crops and animals.

While it is the contention of this essay that—in the long-term, given a sufficiently robust understanding of human well-being—human and non-human flourishing are mutually reinforcing, short-term conflicts between the two surely will arise.

The use of this example points to the difficulty of avoiding consumer culture, which excels at obscuring interconnections. Unless we break away from society entirely, most actions we take involve engagement with consumer culture, whether this is buying seeds for our organic garden or purchasing used crampons at a mountaineering store or buying advertisements in a newspaper to advocate for a particular ecosocial cause. Still, a concern for ecosocial flourishing can reveal the ways we are complicit with the negative consequences of consumerism and can help us try to find small pockets of resistance to this culture.

Of course, Americans also point to the importance of interspecies dialogue. Derrick Jensen (2004) describes many of his own experiences communicating with wolves, chickens, and mice, among other creatures. Jim Merckel (2003) gives another arresting example: after years of exploring his local forest and listening to its many communications, he can instinctively find patches of nettles for meals (146).

For a refreshing antidote to this attitude, see Randall (2007,65) who describes the Tseringma “anti-expedition” of Naess, Faarlund, and Kvaløy, the three most prominent Norwegian ecophilosopher-mountaineers. Tseringma, a Himalayan mountain, is revered by the local Sherpas, who believe it is sacrilegious to climb it. The three philosophers hiked around the base of the mountain in protest of planned attempts by various foreigners to climb the mountain.
